qa_pairs.question: What mindset changes does Angelo Wilson believe are necessary regarding housing and development in the city?
qa_pairs.answer: There's a whole lot of mindset that has to be changed, and you can't burden the people that are now rich in homes and low-density places in the city because they prevented a lot of people from developing over the years.

qa_pairs.answer: The politicians themselves in the city are a block on housing, and maybe you need to get rid of some politicians.

qa_pairs.question: How does Angelo Wilson feel about the development in old neighborhoods?
qa_pairs.answer: I like old neighborhoods and I want to see some kind of development in those neighborhoods. I think rich people or people in low-density areas have to trust that people here for jobs who want to raise their kids want a decent neighborhood too and they're not going to butcher their neighborhoods.

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson think about the commodification of housing?
qa_pairs.answer: If you commodify housing, it becomes whatever you can get out of it, and the easiest way to make a profit is to find the cheapest place to build, which runs everybody out of the cheaper neighborhoods.
qa_pairs.source_text: and if you if you if you commodify housing it becomes whatever you can get out of it and and the easiest way to make a profit is find the cheapest place to build which is Hunters Point which is the mission you know is the cheapest place to build and maximize your profit which runs everybody out of the cheaper neighborhoods

qa_pairs.question: What is Angelo Wilson's opinion on the development of downtown San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: I didn't want the development of this downtown anyhow. We built all of this downtown, nobody lives in it, and all the south of Market flop houses are gone.

qa_pairs.question: How does Angelo Wilson describe the treatment of poor people in the city?
qa_pairs.answer: There's no attention to those folks; they don't care about poor people. It's a non-profit racket, a billion dollars a year to scrape crap off the street.

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson suggest about regional planning for housing?
qa_pairs.answer: You have to start thinking more regionally about who is going to live where and make sure the services are there for people that want to live there.
qa_pairs.source_text: you have to start think thinking I think in general in in more Regional regionally whos going to live where make sure the services are there for people that want to live there

qa_pairs.question: What is Angelo Wilson's perspective on the affordability of housing?
qa_pairs.answer: It's not affordable because you have policies that don't provide for affordability, and all you're doing is saying okay now we're going to build more houses which makes the policies that were in place to elevate the cost of housing even more.
qa_pairs.source_text: its not affordable because you have policies that dont provide for affordability and all youre doing is saying okay now were going to build more more houses which makes the policies that were in place to elevate the cost of housing even more

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson think about the current state of housing development policies?
qa_pairs.answer: The plans work hand in hand with existing policies, and if you're going to start a new game, you should whack the board clean and say okay we have a density of six units per lot in every neighborhood.

qa_pairs.question: What does Angelo Wilson recall about his mother's reaction to the Presidio when they first arrived in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: My mother looked around the Presidio and said, 'Oh, this is nice, this is much too nice for poor people.'
qa_pairs.source_text: Ill tell you the story about my mother when she got out of the car when we just we had just came from France in 64 and she out of the car looked around the Presidio thats where we were going to live the first three years here thats where I lived she looked around and said oh this is nice this is much too nice for poor people
